question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work.} Simplification of answers is not required.

Evaluate the following integral.

\[\int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)}.\]
sols:
We recognize a denominator of the form $x^2+a^2$ and so we attempt a
trigonometric substitution of the form

\[x = 2\tan \theta, \quad dx = 2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta.\]

Then the integral becomes

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} &= \int \frac{2\sec^2 \theta\,d\theta}{2\tan \theta \underbrace{(4\tan^2\theta+4)}_{=4\sec^2\theta}} \\
&= \int \frac{d\theta}{4\tan\theta} = \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta}.
\end{align*}

To solve this integral we use another substitution:

\[u = \sin \theta, \quad du = \cos \theta\,d\theta,\]

to obtain

\begin{align*}
\frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,d\theta}{\sin \theta} &= \frac14 \int \frac{\cos \theta\,du}{u \cos \theta} \\
&= \frac14 \int \frac{du}{u} = \frac14 \ln|u| +C\\
&= \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C.
\end{align*}

To revert back to an expression with $x$ we have to calculate
$\sin \theta.$

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2008_Question_3_(c)_picture1.png}
\caption{Math\_Exam\_Resources\_Courses\_MATH101\_April\_2008\_Question\_3\_(c)\_picture1.png}
\end{figure}

So we use a reference triangle. The sides $x$ and $2$ are given from the
substitution $\tan \theta = x/2.$ With Pythagoras we can then calculate
the length of the remaining side of the triangle, which is
$\color{red}\sqrt{x^2+4}$. Hence our final answer is

\[\int \frac{dx}{x(x^2+4)} = \frac14 \ln|\sin \theta| +C = \frac{1}{4}\ln\left|\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+4}}\right| +C.\]
hints:
There are (at least) two distinct ways to solve this.

Option 1: Start with a trigonometric substitution.

Option 2: Use partial fractions.

Option 1: Your first trigonometric substitution should make use of the
fact that $a^2+a^2\tan^2\theta = a^2\sec^2\theta.$

Option 2: How do set up partial fraction when the denominator does not
factor into linear factors?
